sn36.8:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn36.8:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to the infirmary, where
sn36.8:4.3: he sat down on the indicated seat,
sn36.8:5.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
sn36.8:5.2: This is my instruction to you.
sn36.8:6.1: And how is a mendicant mindful?
sn36.8:6.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn36.8:6.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn36.8:6.4: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind …
sn36.8:6.5: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn36.8:6.6: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
sn36.8:7.1: And how is a mendicant aware?
sn36.8:7.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
sn36.8:7.4: That’s how a mendicant is aware.
sn36.8:7.5: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
sn36.8:7.6: This is my instruction to you.
sn36.8:8.1: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:
sn36.8:8.3: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.
sn36.8:8.7: But this contact is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
sn36.8:8.8: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on contact that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?”
sn36.8:8.9: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in contact and pleasant feeling.
sn36.8:8.10: As they do so, they give up the tendency for greed for contact and pleasant feeling.
sn36.8:9.1: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise …
sn36.8:9.3: if neutral feelings arise, they understand:
sn36.8:9.5: ‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.
sn36.8:9.9: (Expand in detail as in the previous discourse.)
sn36.8:9.10: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’
sn36.8:10.1: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn. As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.
sn36.8:10.2: In the same way, feeling the end of the body, a mendicant understands: ‘I feel the end of the body.’ Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn36.8:10.3: Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn36.8:10.4: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
